summary_points.title: Cautious Start Amid Mixed Global Cues
summary_points.summary: Indian benchmark indices Sensex and Nifty 50 are poised for a marginally higher open, with Gift Nifty signaling a positive bias. However, investors remain cautious amid mixed moves in Asian markets, a softer finish on Wall Street and ongoing scrutiny of India–China relations.

summary_points.title: Three-Day Losing Streak Extends Technical Weakness
summary_points.summary: The domestic market extended its losing run to three sessions, with Nifty 50 slipping below the 24,500 mark. Weekly charts for Sensex reveal a long bearish candle and a lower‐top formation, underscoring a negative technical outlook.

summary_points.title: US Tariff Uncertainty Looms Over Markets
summary_points.summary: Concerns over President Trump’s tariffs persist, weighing on sentiment. A recent U.S. appeals court decision declaring most Trump-era tariffs unlawful—but allowing them to remain in effect until mid-October—adds further ambiguity to India’s trade outlook.

summary_points.title: GDP Outperformance Fuels Early-September Rally
summary_points.summary: Stronger-than-expected June-quarter GDP growth of 7.8% provided a boost to market sentiment. Positive domestic economic data helped Sensex and Nifty achieve a firmer start to September after two consecutive monthly declines.

summary_points.title: Key Triggers to Watch This Week
summary_points.summary: Investors will closely monitor developments on U.S. tariffs, auto sales numbers, the GST Council meeting outcome, foreign fund flows, forthcoming domestic and global macroeconomic data, and crude oil price movements.

summary_points.title: Domestic Demand Themes Offer Sectoral Opportunity
summary_points.summary: Consumption-driven and domestic growth-oriented sectors—including FMCG, durables, discretionary stocks, cement and infrastructure—are well-positioned to benefit from anticipated GST rate cuts, firm underlying demand and increased government spending.

top_performers.explanation: With GST cuts and resilient domestic demand, the fast-moving consumer goods space is set to benefit from steady consumption trends.
Lower tax rates and ongoing retail demand are boosting sales of consumer electronics and household appliances.
Rising retail income and favorable government spending are supporting growth in discretionary spending categories.

underperformers.explanation: Heightened risk aversion amid tariff worries and liquidity concerns has led investors to trim midcap exposures more sharply.
Similar to midcaps, small-caps have borne the brunt of sell-offs as foreign and domestic funds de-risk portfolios.
Fears over US tariffs and global trade tensions are weighing on export-dependent technology and automobile names.

market_drivers.summary: Today’s Indian market slipped into a cautious mood as weak global cues – led by a US federal appeals court upholding Trump’s reciprocal tariffs, softer US inflation data and lower Asian bourses – weighed on sentiment in the absence of clear domestic triggers. Investors remained on the sidelines ahead of the GST Council meeting, where talks over potential rate rationalization and broader GST reforms are expected to set the next policy tone, while foreign institutional flows stayed subdued. Sectoral divergences were pronounced, with metal and IT names under pressure even as FMCG and banking stocks provided limited support, and farm‐linked sectors, including tractor makers buoyed by ICRA’s upbeat demand outlook, managed to hold ground. Technical indicators on Sensex and Nifty also signalled a negative bias, underscoring the need for clearer consolidation or fresh catalysts before participants step up risk exposure.
